title: Behavioral Pain Scale (BPS) for Pain Assessment in Intubated Patients
description: Quantifies pain in critically ill intubated patients who cannot self-report using three behavioral indicators

parameters.name: facial_expression
parameters.description: Assessment of facial expression as indicator of pain in intubated patient

parameters.name: upper_limb_movements
parameters.description: Assessment of upper limb movement patterns indicating pain or distress

parameters.name: compliance_with_ventilation
parameters.description: Assessment of patient's compliance with mechanical ventilation
options: 2 - Coughing but tolerating ventilation for most of the time

result.name: bps_score
result.description: BPS score from 3 (no pain) to 12 (maximum pain)

ranges.interpretation: Patient demonstrates no pain behaviors. Continue current management with routine monitoring. No analgesic intervention required.
Patient demonstrates mild pain behaviors. Consider comfort measures and reassessment. May consider low-dose analgesics based on clinical context.

ranges.description: Unacceptable amount of pain requiring intervention
ranges.interpretation: Patient demonstrates significant pain behaviors requiring intervention. Consider sedation and/or analgesia according to institutional protocols. Reassess after intervention.
Patient demonstrates maximum pain behaviors requiring immediate intervention. Administer appropriate analgesia and sedation. Consider multimodal pain management approach.

references: Payen JF, Bru O, Bosson JL, Lagrasta A, Novel E, Deschaux I, et al. Assessing pain in critically ill sedated patients by using a behavioral pain scale. Crit Care Med. 2001 Dec;29(12):2258-63.

Ahlers SJ, van Gulik L, van der Veen AM, van Dongen HP, de Boer A, Tibboel D, et al. Comparison of different pain scoring systems in critically ill patients in a general ICU. Crit Care. 2008;12(1):R15.

Chanques G, Sebbane M, Barbotte E, Viel E, Eledjam JJ, Jaber S. A prospective study of pain at rest: incidence and characteristics of an unrecognized symptom in surgical and trauma versus medical intensive care unit patients. Anesthesiology. 2007 Nov;107(5):858-60.
formula: BPS Score = Facial Expression (1-4) + Upper Limb Movements (1-4) + Compliance with Ventilation (1-4)
notes: Designed specifically for critically ill intubated patients unable to self-report pain
Scores â‰¥6 indicate unacceptable pain requiring sedation and/or analgesia
Should be assessed at rest and during noxious stimuli
Recommended assessment frequency: once per shift or when analgesia changes
Validated in multiple ICU populations including surgical, trauma, and medical patients
One of the two recommended behavioral pain scales in 2018 PADIS guidelines (along with CPOT)
Particularly applicable to mechanically ventilated patients due to ventilation compliance component
More difficult to use in patients under deep sedation
